title: Fitts's Law
oneLiner: Larger, closer targets are faster to reach
definition: The time required to move to a target depends on the target's size and distance. Larger targets that are closer to the starting position can be acquired faster than smaller, more distant targets.
do: Make important buttons larger and easier to hit
Place frequently used controls closer to users' natural hand positions
Ensure touch targets are at least 44pt (iOS) or 48dp (Android)
Position related actions close together
dont: Make critical buttons too small or hard to reach
Place important actions at screen edges on large displays
Use tiny touch targets that require precision
Separate related actions by large distances

example.caption: Mobile keyboards place frequently used keys larger and closer to thumbs

title: Hick's Law
oneLiner: More options → slower decisions
definition: The time it takes to make a decision increases logarithmically with the number of choices available. Users become overwhelmed and decision-making slows when presented with too many options.
do: Limit menu items to 5-7 main categories
Use progressive disclosure to reveal options gradually
Group similar options together logically
Highlight recommended or popular choices
dont: Present all options at once without organization
Create menus with more than 7-10 items
Force users to choose from dozens of similar options
Hide important actions too deeply

example.caption: Netflix uses categories and recommendations to reduce choice overload

title: Miller's Rule
oneLiner: People can only hold 7±2 items in working memory
definition: The average person can hold about 7 (plus or minus 2) items in their working memory at once. This applies to navigation menus, form fields, and any interface requiring users to remember multiple pieces of information.
do: Limit main navigation to 5-9 items maximum
Break long forms into smaller, logical sections
Use chunking to group related information
Provide clear progress indicators for multi-step processes
dont: Create navigation menus with more than 9 top-level items
Present long lists without categorization
Design forms with too many fields on one screen
Expect users to remember complex sequences

example.caption: Phone numbers are chunked (555-123-4567) to aid memory

title: Jakob's Law
oneLiner: Users expect your site to work like other sites they know
definition: Users spend most of their time on other websites and mobile apps, so they prefer your site to work the same way as all the other sites they already know. Consistency with established patterns reduces cognitive load.
do: Follow established design patterns and conventions
Place navigation where users expect it (top or left)
Use familiar icons and interaction patterns
Match user expectations for common actions
dont: Reinvent common interface patterns unnecessarily
Place navigation in unexpected locations
Use unconventional icons without labels
Create unique flows for standard actions

example.caption: E-commerce sites consistently place shopping carts in the top-right corner

title: Pareto Principle
oneLiner: 80% of effects come from 20% of causes
definition: Also known as the 80/20 rule, this principle suggests that roughly 80% of outcomes result from 20% of inputs. In UX, 80% of users typically use only 20% of features, so focus design effort on those critical features.
do: Identify the 20% of features used by 80% of users
Make the most important features easily accessible
Prioritize optimization efforts on high-impact areas
Design primary actions prominently
dont: Give equal visual weight to all features
Bury commonly used functions in submenus
Spend equal development time on all features
Clutter interfaces with rarely used options

example.caption: Microsoft Office ribbon emphasizes the 20% of features used most often

title: Law of Proximity
oneLiner: Objects close together are perceived as related
definition: Items that are spatially close to each other tend to be perceived as belonging to the same group. This Gestalt principle helps users understand relationships and organize information visually.
do: Group related form fields close together
Place labels near their corresponding inputs
Use consistent spacing to show relationships
Separate unrelated content with white space
dont: Place unrelated elements too close together
Use inconsistent spacing that confuses groupings
Separate labels too far from their inputs
Crowd the interface without logical grouping

example.caption: Form fields are grouped by topic using proximity and spacing

title: Serial Position Effect
oneLiner: Users remember first and last items best
definition: In a list of items, people tend to remember the first few (primacy effect) and last few (recency effect) items best, while items in the middle are more likely to be forgotten or overlooked.
do: Place the most important items at the beginning or end of lists
Position key navigation items at the start or end of menus
End forms with clear call-to-action buttons
Start content with compelling hooks
dont: Bury important items in the middle of long lists
Place critical navigation in the center of menus
Hide important information in the middle of content
Make all list items look equally important

example.caption: Netflix places trending content at the top and personalized picks at the bottom

title: Zeigarnik Effect
oneLiner: People remember interrupted tasks better than completed ones
definition: Incomplete or interrupted tasks are better remembered than completed tasks. This creates mental tension that keeps the task active in memory until it's finished, which can be leveraged to increase engagement.
do: Show progress indicators to create completion desire
Use progress bars in multi-step processes
Highlight partially completed profiles or forms
Create natural stopping points in long content
dont: Leave users without clear next steps
Create overly complex multi-step processes
Make progress indicators misleading or inaccurate
Force completion of unnecessary steps

example.caption: LinkedIn shows profile completion percentage to encourage finishing

title: Peak-End Rule
oneLiner: People judge experiences by their peak moment and how they end
definition: Users remember an experience largely based on how they felt at its peak (most intense point) and at its end, rather than the total sum or average of every moment. The duration has little effect on the memory.
do: Design memorable positive peak moments
End experiences on a high note with celebration or success
Focus on making critical moments delightful
Provide satisfying completion states
dont: End experiences with frustration or confusion
Make the most intensive moments negative
Ignore the emotional journey of user interactions
Focus only on efficiency without considering feelings

example.caption: Uber's trip completion shows route summary and easy rating (positive ending)

title: Von Restorff Effect
oneLiner: Different things stand out and are remembered better
definition: Also known as the isolation effect, items that stand out from their surroundings are more likely to be remembered. Visual distinctiveness helps important elements capture attention and improve recall.
do: Make primary actions visually distinct from secondary ones
Use color, size, or typography to highlight key information
Ensure important buttons stand out from the background
Create visual hierarchy through contrast
dont: Make everything look the same without hierarchy
Overuse highlighting, making everything compete for attention
Hide important actions with low contrast
Use distinctiveness for unimportant elements

example.caption: Spotify's green 'Play' button stands out distinctly from other interface elements

title: Confirmation Bias
oneLiner: People seek information that confirms their existing beliefs
definition: The tendency to search for, interpret, and recall information that confirms pre-existing beliefs while ignoring contradictory evidence. Users approach interfaces with preconceptions about how things should work.
do: Present information objectively and clearly
Test designs with diverse user groups
Challenge your own assumptions during design
Provide multiple perspectives on complex topics
dont: Design based solely on your own preferences
Ignore user feedback that contradicts expectations
Present only information that supports your narrative
Skip user testing with different demographic groups

example.caption: News apps often create filter bubbles by showing content similar to past reads

title: Anchoring Bias
oneLiner: First impressions heavily influence all subsequent judgments
definition: People rely heavily on the first piece of information encountered (the 'anchor') when making decisions. This initial information serves as a reference point for all subsequent judgments, even when it's irrelevant.
do: Lead with your strongest value proposition
Show higher-value options first in pricing
Create positive first impressions with polished onboarding
Use anchoring strategically in product presentations
dont: Start with negative or confusing experiences
Hide the most attractive options behind less appealing ones
Create poor first impressions that are hard to overcome
Ignore the power of initial positioning

example.caption: SaaS pricing pages often show the premium plan first to anchor expectations high

title: Loss Aversion
oneLiner: People fear losing something more than gaining equivalent value
definition: The psychological principle that people feel the pain of losing something twice as strongly as the pleasure of gaining the same thing. Users are more motivated to avoid losses than to acquire gains of equal value.
do: Frame benefits in terms of what users will lose without them
Provide clear warnings before destructive actions
Offer to save or backup important user data
Emphasize existing investments when preventing churn
dont: Delete user data without clear warnings
Remove features without explaining alternatives
Make it easy to accidentally lose progress or content
Focus only on gains without acknowledging potential losses

example.caption: Spotify shows 'You'll lose your playlists' when users try to downgrade

title: Choice Overload
oneLiner: Too many options can paralyze decision-making
definition: When faced with too many choices, people often experience decision paralysis, make poorer choices, or avoid deciding altogether. The paradox of choice suggests that while some choice is good, too much choice can be overwhelming.
do: Curate and limit options to the most relevant ones
Provide smart defaults and recommendations
Use progressive disclosure to reveal options gradually
Group similar options into clear categories
dont: Present hundreds of options without filtering
Make users configure everything from scratch
Offer choices without guidance or recommendations
Create equally prominent options for all features

example.caption: Apple offers just a few iPhone models instead of dozens of configurations

title: Availability Heuristic
oneLiner: People judge likelihood by how easily examples come to mind
definition: People estimate the probability or frequency of an event based on how easily they can recall similar instances. Recent, memorable, or frequently encountered examples seem more likely to occur than they actually are.
do: Provide concrete examples to illustrate abstract concepts
Use familiar analogies to explain new features
Make important information memorable and accessible
Share relevant case studies and success stories
dont: Rely on users to imagine abstract scenarios
Assume users understand risks without examples
Hide important information that should be easily recalled
Use only statistical data without concrete examples

example.caption: Password managers show recent data breaches to motivate security improvements

title: Dunning-Kruger Effect
oneLiner: People with low ability overestimate their competence
definition: Individuals with limited knowledge or competence in a domain overestimate their own knowledge or competence in that domain. This affects how users perceive their skill level and their willingness to seek help or follow guidance.
do: Provide progressive learning paths for complex features
Offer both beginner and advanced modes
Make help and tutorials easily accessible
Guide users through complex tasks step-by-step
dont: Assume all users know their actual skill level
Hide help systems or make them hard to find
Design only for expert users
Skip educational content for complex features

example.caption: Adobe products offer both simple and advanced modes for different skill levels

title: Sunk Cost Fallacy
oneLiner: People continue bad decisions because they've already invested
definition: The tendency to continue investing in a losing proposition because of previously invested resources (time, money, or effort). Users may stick with poor solutions simply because they've already put effort into them.
do: Acknowledge users' previous investments when proposing changes
Provide migration tools and clear transition paths
Explain future benefits that outweigh past investments
Make new solutions clearly superior to old ones
dont: Ignore the effort users have put into current workflows
Make switching costly or complicated
Dismiss existing solutions without showing better alternatives
Force changes without explaining long-term benefits

example.caption: Google provided clear migration tools when shutting down Google Reader

title: Recognition over Recall
oneLiner: It's easier to recognize things than to remember them
definition: Human memory is better at recognizing previously encountered items than recalling them from scratch. Users find it easier to choose from a list of options than to generate answers from memory.
do: Provide dropdown menus instead of requiring typed input
Show recently used items or suggestions
Use autocomplete and search suggestions
Display available options clearly
dont: Force users to remember exact commands or syntax
Hide available options behind unclear labels
Require users to recall precise formatting
Make users guess what inputs are acceptable

example.caption: Google's search suggestions help users recognize what they're looking for

title: Consistency & Standards
oneLiner: Similar things should look and behave the same way
definition: Users should not have to wonder whether different words, situations, or actions mean the same thing. Consistency within your product and adherence to platform conventions reduces cognitive load and improves usability.
do: Use consistent terminology throughout your product
Apply the same interaction patterns for similar actions
Follow platform-specific design guidelines
Maintain visual consistency across all screens
dont: Use different words for the same concept
Change interaction patterns arbitrarily between screens
Ignore platform conventions without good reason
Create inconsistent visual treatments for similar elements

example.caption: iOS apps consistently use swipe-right for 'back' navigation

title: Error Prevention
oneLiner: Prevent problems before they occur
definition: Good design prevents users from making errors in the first place. This involves eliminating error-prone conditions, asking for confirmation of destructive actions, and providing constraints that guide users toward correct choices.
do: Validate inputs in real-time as users type
Ask for confirmation before destructive actions
Provide clear constraints and formatting examples
Disable buttons that would cause errors
dont: Wait until form submission to show validation errors
Allow destructive actions without warning
Accept clearly invalid input without guidance
Make it easy to accidentally trigger critical actions

example.caption: Gmail asks 'Send anyway?' when you mention 'attachment' but haven't attached anything
